title: Time Series Analysis
text:
A time series is any sequence of measurements taken at regular, equally spaced intervals—seconds, minutes, hours, days, months, quarters, or years. Common examples include weather (daily temperature or rainfall), financial markets (daily stock prices or returns), industry indicators (monthly production or sales), electricity demand, traffic counts, and hospital admissions. In time-series analysis we study how these values evolve: their level, trend, seasonal or calendar patterns (e.g., weekdays vs. weekends, holiday effects), cycles, and anomalies. Typical goals are to describe behavior clearly, forecast future values, and quantify the impact of events or policies.
Because observations are ordered in time, nearby points tend to be correlated (autocorrelation). This violates the independent-and-identically-distributed assumption behind many standard statistical methods, so naïve cross-sectional tools often mislead. Time-series work must explicitly handle dependence, trend, and seasonality—for example by differencing, seasonal adjustment, and models that use lagged values and errors (e.g., ARIMA/SARIMA, ARIMAX/SARIMAX with external drivers, VAR for multiple series, state-space/ETS, or GARCH when volatility changes over time). Analysts also watch for structural breaks (e.g., policy shifts, COVID), outliers, and missing periods, and they evaluate models with time-aware validation (rolling or blocked splits) rather than random shuffles.

title: Time Series Analysis
section: Project Idea: Volatility Spillovers Across Asset Classes
text:
Project Idea: Volatility Spillovers Across Asset Classes
Crypto → Equity Spillovers
Outcomes: Daily return volatility of Bitcoin, Ethereum, altcoin index, and S&P 500.
Covariates: Trading volume, Fed policy announcements, macro uncertainty indices.
Models: VAR-based Diebold–Yilmaz connectedness index; Interrupted Time Series (ITS) around shocks like FTX collapse or major Fed hikes.
Crypto → Commodities (Digital Gold Hypothesis)
Outcomes: BTC–Gold return correlations, BTC–Oil volatility interactions.
Covariates: Inflation announcements, commodity price shocks, geopolitical events.
Models: DCC-GARCH to track time-varying correlations; BEKK-GARCH for volatility transmission direction.
Crypto → Volatility Index (Fear Gauge)
Outcomes: Spillovers between Bitcoin volatility and the VIX index (equity “fear gauge”).
Covariates: S&P 500 returns, macro policy shocks, crypto-specific crashes.
Models: Threshold-GARCH to capture nonlinear effects; VAR event studies around high-volatility windows.
Frequency Decomposition of Spillovers
Outcomes: Short-run vs. long-run volatility spillovers across BTC, ETH, S&P500, Gold, and VIX.
Covariates: Same core series, separated into frequency bands.
Models: Baruník–Křehlík frequency connectedness to show whether crypto influence is trader-driven (short-term) or macro-driven (long-term).
Time-Varying Connectedness
Outcomes: Net transmitter vs. net receiver roles of BTC and ETH during calm vs. crisis periods (COVID crash, Terra/FTX collapse, banking stress).
Covariates: Event dummies for stress regimes.
Models: TVP-VAR connectedness (time-varying without rolling windows); structural break tests.
Stablecoins and Market Stability
Outcomes: USDT/USDC de-pegging episodes, before/after volatility in broader crypto markets.
Covariates: Stablecoin volume, liquidity shocks, macro stress events.
Models: Interrupted Time Series around de-peg dates; ARIMAX with stablecoin activity as an exogenous regressor.
Research Papers
Diebold & Yilmaz (2012): Better to Give than to Receive: Predictive Directional Measurement of Volatility Spillovers — foundational connectedness index.
Engle (2002): Dynamic Conditional Correlation: A Simple Class of Multivariate GARCH Models — for evolving correlations.
Engle & Kroner (1995): Multivariate Simultaneous GARCH — BEKK parameterization for volatility spillovers.
Baruník & Křehlík (2018): Measuring the Frequency Dynamics of Financial Connectedness — short-run vs long-run spillover methods.
Antonakakis & Gabauer (2017, 2018): Time-Varying Parameter VAR-based Connectedness Measures — dynamic connectedness without rolling windows.
Recent empirical studies show that crypto shocks spill into equities, commodities, bonds, and volatility indices, especially during stress periods (COVID, 2022 crashes, Fed rate hikes).

title: Introduction
text:
This project explores the connected nature of modern financial markets by examining how volatility, price fluctuation and market uncertainty spread across different asset classes. This analysis specifically focuses on the emerging cryptocurrency market and how they may influence traditional financial instruments, including equities, commodities, bonds, and volatility indices.
Volatility spillovers occur when price shocks or periods of uncertainty in one market affect other markets, creating a domino effect of financial instability or opportunity. While traditional spillover research has long studied connections between established markets (such as how U.S. stock market crashes affect European markets), the rapid growth of cryptocurrency markets has introduced an entirely new dynamic to global financial systems.
The central question driving this research is: How do cryptocurrency market fluctuations propagate through traditional financial markets, and what does this mean for investors, regulators, and the broader economy? This investigation is particularly relevant given recent events such as the 2022 cryptocurrency market collapse, the FTX exchange failure, Federal Reserve interest rate policies, and ongoing debates about cryptocurrency regulation and systemic risk.
Unlike traditional financial assets backed by physical assets or cash flows, cryptocurrencies represent a new category of digital assets with unique characteristics: 24/7 trading, high volatility, limited regulation, and strong retail investor participation. Understanding how these distinctive features interact with established financial markets is crucial for modern portfolio management, risk assessment, and financial stability monitoring.
This analysis goes beyond simple correlation studies to examine the directional flow of volatility, the persistence of spillover effects, and how these relationships change during different market conditions—from calm periods to major financial crises.

title: Introduction
section: Foundational Spillover Methodology and Traditional Markets
text:
Foundational Spillover Methodology and Traditional Markets
The measurement of volatility spillovers has been revolutionized by the work of Diebold and Yilmaz (2012), who developed a generalized vector autoregressive framework in which forecast-error variance decompositions are invariant to variable ordering, enabling measures of both total and directional volatility spillovers. Their analysis of US stock, bond, foreign exchange, and commodities markets from 1999 to 2010 demonstrated that cross-market volatility spillovers were quite limited until the global financial crisis, which began in 2007, with particularly important spillovers from the stock market to other markets taking place after the collapse of Lehman Brothers in September 2008. This methodology has been extended by Engle (2002) with Dynamic Conditional Correlation models for evolving correlations, and by Baruník and Křehlík (2018), who introduced frequency-domain analysis to distinguish between short-run trader-driven spillovers and long-run fundamental economic relationships. Recent methodological advances include Antonakakis and Gabauer (2017), who refined these measures to capture time-varying connectedness using TVP-VAR methods that provide more dynamic and sensitive connectedness measurements, particularly when relationships in the system do not remain constant over time.

title: Introduction
text:
Cryptocurrency Integration and Cross-Market Spillovers
The emergence of cryptocurrency markets has fundamentally altered the landscape of financial spillovers, with mounting evidence of significant transmission effects to traditional asset classes. Recent studies demonstrate significant adverse volatility spillover effects from the cryptocurrency market to financial markets across various regions, including North America, South America, Europe, and Asia, with shocks originating in the cryptocurrency market negatively impacting stock markets, volatility indices, and foreign exchange rates globally. Research by the International Monetary Fund (2023) reveals that crypto assets predominantly transmit spillovers to financial markets, though reversals occur during periods of financial stress, with the magnitude of spillovers increasing during periods of heightened turbulence due to negative economic-financial news or crypto market events. The COVID-19 pandemic served as a natural experiment, with empirical analysis showing that the pandemic amplified volatility spillovers, thereby intensifying financial contagion between markets, indicating that the pandemic’s impact on the economy heightened risk transmission across markets. Notably, recent Chinese market evidence from 2018-2024 shows that cryptocurrency price volatility causes stock market prices to fluctuate in the same direction while causing gold market prices to fluctuate in the opposite direction, challenging traditional safe-haven assumptions.

title: Introduction
section: Crisis Dynamics, Frequency Effects, and Research Gaps
text:
Crisis Dynamics, Frequency Effects, and Research Gaps
The literature reveals that spillover relationships exhibit distinct patterns during crisis periods and across different time horizons, highlighting the importance of frequency-domain analysis and time-varying methodologies. Studies show that heightened crude oil volatility, stock volatility, and economic policy uncertainty contribute to more significant liquidity spillovers within cryptocurrency markets, with increased volatility in exchange rates, crude oil, gold, and stock markets enhancing Ethereum’s role as a transmitter of liquidity shocks. Research using DCC-GARCH and wavelet analysis during COVID-19 demonstrates that volatility spillovers in cryptocurrency markets exhibit information inefficiency characteristics, with mutual linkages reflected through volatility co-movement, lead/lag effects, and systematic risk transmission. However, despite these advances, significant gaps remain in the literature. Most existing studies focus on either cryptocurrency-to-crypto spillovers or limited bilateral relationships with specific traditional assets, rather than comprehensive multi-asset class analysis. Additionally, research indicates that extreme fluctuations not predicted by current models are primarily caused by sudden external events, suggesting that existing methods are better suited for early warning of endogenous market volatility rather than exogenous shocks. This project addresses these gaps by providing a systematic analysis of directional spillovers across multiple asset classes while incorporating both crisis-period dynamics and frequency-decomposed effects to better understand the evolving role of cryptocurrencies in global financial stability.

title: Introduction
text:
Analytical Angles
Our volatility spillover analysis is structured around five distinct perspectives, each offering nsights into cryptocurrency-traditional market interactions:

Crypto-Equity Spillovers: Examining how Bitcoin and Ethereum volatility influences stock market dynamics
Digital Gold Hypothesis: Testing whether Bitcoin functions as a safe haven asset comparable to gold
Fear Gauge Interactions: Analyzing relationships between crypto volatility and market fear indicators (VIX)
Frequency Analysis: Decomposing spillovers into short-term trader effects versus long-term economic relationships
Crisis Dynamics & Stablecoins: Understanding how market relationships change during stress periods and stablecoin events

title: Introduction
text:
Guiding Questions
Our analysis addresses twelve fundamental questions that span directional spillovers, market-specific interactions, temporal patterns, and crisis dynamics:

Directional Spillover Analysis

Which direction is dominant: Do cryptocurrency markets transmit volatility to traditional markets, or do they receive volatility from them?
What is the magnitude of spillover effects: How much of the variance in traditional market volatility can be explained by cryptocurrency market shocks?
How persistent are these effects: Do crypto-induced volatility spillovers last hours, days, or weeks in traditional markets?



Market-Specific Interactions

Does Bitcoin truly behave like “digital gold”: Under what market conditions does Bitcoin correlate positively vs. negatively with gold prices, and when does this relationship break down?
How does crypto volatility relate to the VIX “fear gauge”: Do cryptocurrency market crashes predict spikes in equity market fear, or do they respond to existing market stress?
Which traditional market sectors are most vulnerable: Are technology stocks more susceptible to crypto spillovers than utility or consumer staple sectors?



Temporal and Frequency Analysis

Do spillover patterns exhibit seasonality: Are there weekly (weekend effects), monthly (options expiry), or quarterly (earnings season) patterns in volatility transmission?
How do short-term vs. long-term spillovers differ: Are crypto spillovers primarily driven by high-frequency trading noise or by fundamental economic relationships?
How have spillover relationships evolved over time: Have cryptocurrencies become more or less connected to traditional markets as they’ve matured?



Crisis and Event Analysis

How do major events reshape market connections: What was the impact of specific events like the FTX collapse, COVID-19 market crash, or Federal Reserve rate hikes on spillover dynamics?
Do stablecoin de-pegging events amplify broader market volatility: When USDT or USDC lose their dollar peg, does this create systemic risk beyond crypto markets?
Can we identify early warning signals: Are there leading indicators in cryptocurrency markets that predict broader financial market stress before traditional measures like the VIX?

These questions will guide our analysis and may evolve as findings emerge from exploratory data analysis and model estimation.

title: Introduction
text:
Data Requirements Overview
Our analysis satisfies the course requirements by incorporating:

Seasonality data: Cryptocurrency markets exhibit strong weekly patterns (weekday vs. weekend effects), monthly patterns, and holiday seasonality
Financial assets: Multiple asset classes including cryptocurrencies, equities, commodities, bonds, and volatility indices
3+ univariate time series per analytical angle: Each of our five angles incorporates multiple distinct time series for comprehensive analysis

Examining how cryptocurrency volatility influences stock market dynamics

Source: Yahoo Finance API & CoinGecko API

import yfinance as yf
btc_data = yf.download('BTC-USD', start='2018-01-01', end='2024-12-31')

Source: CoinGecko API & Yahoo Finance
Description: Daily price and volume data for Ethereum (ETH-USD)
Frequency: Daily from 2018-present
Acquisition Method: RESTful API calls to CoinGecko with rate limiting

Source: FRED Economic Data & Yahoo Finance
Description: Daily closing values and returns for the S&P 500 index
Frequency: Daily market data (excluding weekends/holidays)
Acquisition Method: Direct download from FRED API or Yahoo Finance API

title: Introduction
text:
Angle 3: Fear Gauge Interactions
Analyzing relationships between crypto volatility and market fear indicators

VIX Index

Source: CBOE & Yahoo Finance
Description: Chicago Board Options Exchange Volatility Index (fear gauge)
Frequency: Daily market data
Calculation: Implied volatility from S&P 500 options
Crisis Indicators: Spikes above 30 indicate high fear, above 40 indicate extreme fear



Bitcoin Realized Volatility

Source: Calculated from Bitcoin price data (CoinGecko/Yahoo Finance)
Description: Historical volatility measures using various estimators
Calculation Methods:

Parkinson estimator (high-low volatility)
Garman-Klass-Yang-Zhang estimator

Simple realized volatility (squared returns)

Frequency: Daily, with 5-minute intraday data when available
Rolling Windows: 7-day, 30-day, and 90-day volatility measures



Crypto Fear & Greed Index

Source: Alternative.me API
Description: Sentiment indicator for cryptocurrency markets (0-100 scale)
Components: Volatility, market momentum, social media sentiment, surveys, Bitcoin dominance
Frequency: Daily updates
Acquisition Method: RESTful API with JSON response parsing
Interpretation: 0-24 (Extreme Fear), 25-49 (Fear), 50-74 (Greed), 75-100 (Extreme Greed)

title: Introduction
text:
Angle 5: Crisis Dynamics & Stablecoins
Understanding how market relationships change during stress periods and stablecoin events

Stablecoin De-peg Events

Sources:

USDT: Tether API & CoinGecko
USDC: Centre Consortium & CoinGecko

Description: Real-time pricing data for major stablecoins to identify de-pegging events
De-peg Definition: Price deviation >0.5% from $1.00 USD for >24 hours
Historical Events: May 2022 Terra Luna collapse, March 2023 Silicon Valley Bank crisis
Data Frequency: Hourly pricing data to capture intraday de-pegging



Fed Policy Announcements

Source: Federal Reserve Economic Data (FRED) & Fed Meeting Calendar
Description: FOMC meeting dates, interest rate decisions, and policy statement releases
Event Types: Rate decisions, forward guidance changes, emergency meetings
Frequency: 8 scheduled meetings per year plus emergency meetings
Data Structure: Event dates with binary indicators for rate changes, QE announcements



Major Crypto Crashes

Sources: News archives, exchange data, academic event studies
Description: Timeline of major cryptocurrency market events and crashes
Key Events:

March 2020: COVID-19 market crash
May 2021: China mining ban announcement

November 2022: FTX exchange collapse
March 2023: Banking sector stress (SVB, Credit Suisse)

Data Construction: Event dates with market impact measurement windows
Impact Metrics: 24-hour, 7-day, and 30-day return impacts across asset classes

title: Introduction
text:
Data Processing and Quality Assurance

Data Cleaning Procedures

Missing Data: Forward-fill for weekends, interpolation for holidays
Outlier Detection: Z-score analysis with 3-sigma threshold
Exchange Rate Conversion: All prices converted to USD using daily exchange rates
Timestamp Alignment: UTC standardization across all data sources



Update Frequency

Real-time Sources: CoinGecko, Yahoo Finance (daily updates)
Government Sources: FRED, BLS (official release schedules)
Manual Updates: Crisis event timeline, policy announcement dates



Data Storage and Reproducibility

Format: CSV files with standardized column naming
Version Control: Git repository with data versioning
Code Availability: All data acquisition scripts available in project repository
Documentation: Detailed metadata for each dataset including source changes over time


This data documentation will be updated as the project progresses and additional data sources are incorporated.
